title: 108_s2898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Program Assessment and Results Act". Congress finds that inefficiency and ineffectiveness in Federal programs undermines confidence in the Government, hinders program improvement efforts, handicaps policy making and oversight, and identifies the need to share performance results among similar programs for improvement. The Government Performance and Results Act of 1993 aimed to improve accountability, focus on results, and integrate program performance with budget decisions. It provided a framework for monitoring long-term goals and annual performance of federal departments and agencies. The purpose of SEC. 3 is to provide a framework for monitoring long-term goals and annual performance of federal departments and agencies. The Act aims to improve the Government Performance and Results Act of 1993 by assessing Federal programs to determine strengths and weaknesses, helping the executive branch make informed decisions, and providing information for congressional oversight and spending decisions. The Act aims to improve government performance by assessing federal programs to help make informed spending decisions for the American people. The Act aims to improve government performance by assessing federal programs to help make informed spending decisions for the American people. SEC. 4. PROGRAM ASSESSMENT. The Government Performance and Results Act of 1993 requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to conduct program assessments jointly with federal agencies every 5 fiscal years. Assessments include evaluating program purpose, design, strategic plan, management, and results. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget develops criteria for identifying programs to assess each fiscal year, considering similarities in functions, purposes, and goals. Efforts are made to assess programs more frequently if they are deemed higher priority or special. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget develops criteria for identifying programs to assess each fiscal year, considering similarities in functions, purposes, and goals. Efforts are made to assess programs more frequently if they are deemed higher priority or special. At least 90 days before completing the assessments, the Director must publish a list of programs to be assessed and the criteria to be used. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget develops criteria for identifying programs to assess each fiscal year. The results of the assessments are submitted in a report to Congress along with the next budget. The report includes performance goals, assessment criteria, assessment results, any limitations, and modifications to the Federal Government performance plan. The President must submit program assessments containing classified information to the appropriate congressional committees, along with an appendix listing the assessments and committees. The assessments must be available electronically through the Office of Management and Budget website. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must provide copies of program assessments and appendices containing classified information to the Committee on Government Reform of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Governmental Affairs of the Senate upon request. Classified information refers to matters described in section 552(b)(1)(A) of title 5. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall define and implement guidance for section 1120 of title 31, United States Code, regarding programs. Inherently governmental functions must be performed by Federal employees. This section expires after September 30, 2013. The table of sections in chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code, is amended by adding a new section at the end. SEC. 5. STRATEGIC PLANNING AMENDMENTS. The deadline for the strategic plan is changed to September 30 of each year following a presidential election starting in 2005. Each plan will cover a 4-year period beginning on October 1 after a presidential election.
